Authors:
Yu Ito, Gerardo Lucio Robledo, Laura Iharlegui, Norio
Tanaka
Title:
Phylogeny of Potamogeton (Potamogetonaceae) revisited:
evidence for apparent inter-ploidy hybridization in Argentina
Abstract:
Potamogeton is a group of aquatic plants that has long
been recognized as a taxonomically difficult plant genus due in
primarily to frequently occurring hybridization. Potamogeton hybrids
seldom exhibit obvious morphological characteristics that make accurate
identification of hybrids and non-hybrids difficult. Genetic data
therefore have been used effectively to detect and document hybrids of
Potamogeton. Here we apply a molecular phylogenetic approach to
preliminary investigate hybridization of Potamogeton in Argentina.
Simultaneously performed molecular phylogenetic analyses based on a
combined plastid DNA (atpB-rbcL, psbA-trnH, trnK 5â intron, trnL intron,
trnL-trnF, and rpl20-rps12) and two nuclear DNA (ITS and 5S-NTS) data
sets showed significant topological incongruences regarding the
positions of a single specimen, which was placed with broad-leaved
polyploid species and linear-leaved diploid relatives in plastid and
nuclear phylogenies, respectively. This discrepancy may indicate
inter-ploidy hybridization. This hybridization occurs most probably
between diploid P. berteroanus and octaploid P. illinoensis; the former
and the latter are paternal and maternal donors, respectively.
